overview.business_description: Global supplier of metal and glass packaging products. Operations span beverage cans, food cans, and glass containers across Americas, Europe, and Africa. Spun off Ardagh Metal Packaging (AMP) in 2021 but retained significant stake. Complex corporate structure with multiple issuing entities.
business_positives: Global scale in packaging - essential products
Some secured bonds trading near par (95-102)
overview.fatal_flaw: ACTIVE RESTRUCTURING - Distress score 52. Chapter 15 filed for ARD Finance (holdco). CDS deliverables being challenged in court (Arini vs Tresidor/Laurion). Houlihan Lokey hired. Net leverage 9.0x. NEGATIVE equity (-$3.4bn). Net income NEGATIVE ($466m loss). Senior Unsecured bonds Caa2/CCC rated. Complex multi-entity structure creates intercompany risk. Creditor disputes active.
overview.ownership: Public - listed (NYSE: ARD). Paul Coulson founder/chairman controls via voting shares. Complex structure with AMP spin-off.

credit_opinion.summary: Ardagh is in ACTIVE RESTRUCTURING with distress score of 52 - among highest in portfolio. Chapter 15 filed for ARD Finance holdco. Houlihan Lokey engaged. CDS deliverables being litigated (Arini vs Tresidor/Laurion) creating additional complexity. Net leverage 9.0x with NEGATIVE equity (-$3.4bn) indicates balance sheet insolvency. Senior Secured bonds at 95-102 suggest near-full recovery, but Senior Unsecured at 94-95 facing haircut. Complex multi-entity structure (Ardagh Group, ARD Finance, AMP) creates significant intercompany and structural subordination risk. This is a WORKOUT situation - not a performing credit.

distress_indicators.trading_signals: ACTIVE WORKOUT: Secured at 95-102 (near par - full recovery), Unsecured at 94-95 (haircut expected). Chapter 15 filed. Advisor engaged. CDS litigation adds complexity. Leverage 9.0x, negative equity. Not a performing credit.

lme_risk_proxy.case_study_relevance: ARDAGH IS A KEY LME CASE STUDY demonstrating: (1) holdco structural subordination risk, (2) CDS deliverables manipulation concerns, (3) multi-entity complexity, (4) creditor-on-creditor disputes. Study this case for lessons applicable to other complex structures.
